Award.AwardTitle: Measuring Quantum Dot Interactions Using Coherent Two-Dimensional Spectroscopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical abstract

Semiconductor quantum dots have discrete energy levels similar to those in an atom, thus they are often described as as "artificial atoms". Unlike atoms, the energy level structure of a quantum dot can be engineered, making them attractive for a wide range of applications ranging from highly efficient lasers to quantum information processing. In addition, quantum dots can be embedded in solid-state devices, a key feature for use in applications. When quantum dots are brought into proximity to one another, their interaction results in new states, just as the interaction between atoms results in the formation of molecules. This project will employ a new coherent optical method to observe and characterize the interactions between quantum dots with sufficient spatial resolution to isolate a single dot or a small set of interacting dots. This new optical method is inspired by established magnetic resonance tachniques that are used to determine molecular structure. Furthermore, the spectroscopic technique developed by this project will have broader applications. For example, it could be used to study excitation processes in photovoltaic solar cells. This project will combine research and education by training students in the multidisciplinary field of coherent optical spectroscopy of solid state systems. This training will include the basic science of the interaction of condensed matter systems with light as well as practical aspects of photonics and microfabrication.


Technical Abstract

Semiconductor quantum dots grown by molecular beam epitaxy have possible applications ranging from low-threshold laser diodes to implementing qubits in quantum information science. Epitaxially grown quantum dots have been studied extensively using single dot techniques, however single dot techniques are not as good at probing the coupling between quantum dots. Interactions can dramatically alter the optical and electronic properties of quantum dots. Furthermore, quantum information schemes require that there be controllable interactions between qubits, and hence between quantum dots. This project probes the coupling between quantum dots using a new implementation of optical multi-dimensional coherent spectroscopy based on photocurrent readout and applying it to small ensembles of InGaAs quantum dots. Two-dimensional coherent spectroscopy was originally developed in nuclear magnetic resonance. Over the last decade, there has been extensive progress in implementing two-dimensional spectroscopy in the infrared and optical regions of the spectrum. The principal investigator's group is a leader in developing methods for using it to study electronic transitions in semiconductors using near-infrared light. Recently these studies have included large ensembles of GaAs natural quantum dots and InAs self-assembled quantum dots. However, the methods used so far, based on detecting an optical signal produced by the third-order nonlinear response of the sample, are not appropriate for use on small ensembles of quantum emitters, which will not generate a well formed signal beam. Thus this project uses a new approach to two-dimensional spectroscopy that detects a fourth-order population through measurement of photocurrent. This approach will be applied to InAs quantum dots and quantum dot molecules embedded in a diode structure. The goal is to understand and measure the interactions between quantum dots to advance the fundamental understanding of quantum phenomena in these nanoscale systems. This understanding can improve the design of systems with target quantum mechanical states and dynamics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on developing and applying new methods of performing nonlinear optical spectroscopy using ultrafast pulses of light focused to the diffraction limit, the limit for how tightly light can be focused. The primary method is known as "multidimensional coherent spectroscopy", where the response is measured as function of two (or more) times, for example the time between two of the excitation pulses and the time over which the signal light is emitted, and correlated by taking a two-dimensional Fourier transform. This method allows the effects of inhomogeneous broadening, where the spectral width of the optical emission due to having many oscillators with different frequencies, to be observed and separated from the homogeneous spectral width, which is characteristic of individual oscillators. In addition, it solves a fundamental ambiguiity of simpler methods, namely determining if multiple observed resonances are coupled to one another. If they are coupled, the nature of the coupling can be determined, for example if it is due to the resonances sharing a common state or many-body interactions betweeen the underlying resonances. Two version of this method were developed, one that used photocurrent as the signal and the other that used a coherent optical signal. It was applied to four different samples, a polariton diode, a thin quantum well that exhibits zero-dimensional quantum dot states due to disorder, a single monolayer of a transition metal dichalcogenide (TMDC) encapsulated in hexagonal boron nitride and a TMDC heterostructure.

Intellectual Merit The studies provided important new insight into the properites of these samples.

In the polariton diode, which consists of three quantum well layers embedded in an optical microcavity, multiple anti-crossing between the excitonic resonances and the light confined in the cavity were observed for the first time. These anti-crossings are evidence that the sample is in the "strong-coupling" regime where the cavity-exciton coupling dominates over dissipation. It also provided a first observation of the "excitation ladder" of states in these samples.

In the "natural quantum dot" sample, the method allowed excitonic resonances due to individual excitonic resonances to be observed. By injecting carriers into the residual two-dimensional "quantum-well" states, the coupling between the dots could be controlled. This resolved long standing discrepancies between different measurement approaches regarding the presence of coupling.

The TMDC samples provide a unique challenge due their small size, which has prevented the application of more sophisticated spectroscopic methods. Our results show that the excitonic resonances are inhomogeneously broadened, indicating that there is still disorder presence in the sample, even when encapsulated in hexagonal boron nitride. These results show that the sample should not be thought of as being "perfect" but rather some degree of disorder is still present. The TMDC heterostructure results are still being analyzed, but they show that there is coupling between excitonic resonances in different monolayers.

Broader Impacts The method developed in this project can potentially be used in a large variety of fields as a standard analytical and characterization tool. Toward this end, the project has resulted in a startup company, MonstrSense Technologies, that is developing a product line based on these methods.

The understanding gained from the polariton diode will impact work on polaritons by providing evidence of the excitation ladder and measuring the interaction strength between the polaritons.

The work on natural quantum dots shows that the interactions can be controlled by injecting carriers in the quantum well states. This ability could be useful for quantum information science where controllable interactions between qubits are needed, as the invidual dots are qubit candidates.

The new understanding about the optical properties of TMDCs will be important for efforts to construct heterostructures from these materials, as well as electronic devices.
